posts.title: Live From the Reading Room: The Early Life of Jean Blackwell Hutson
posts.text: In honor of her 103rd birthday, we celebrate the life and pioneering work of former Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture librarian, archivist, and Chief, Jean Blackwell Hutson. Mrs. Hutson's biographer, Sharon Fitzgerald, talks about the early life and career of Mrs. Hutson.

posts.title: Live from the Reading Room: Ella Baker to Potential Members of the NAACP
posts.text: In this 1943 letter, civil rights icon Ella Baker sends a passionate plea for potential members for the NAACP (National Association for the Advancement of Colored People) for a variety of planned initiatives on behalf of the organization. Makiba Foster, our Assistant Chief Librarian, reads the letter aloud.

posts.title: Schomburg Center Research Guide: Dr. Maya Angelou
posts.text: In honor of National Poetry Month, and what would have been her 89th birthday, we celebrate the life and work of, Dr. Maya Angelou, with this Research Guide. Here, you will find an overview of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture’s holdings related to the work and life of this notable poet, writer, journalist, actress, and dancer.

posts.title: The Schomburg Legacy Lives On: The Genius of Deborah Willis
posts.text: In honor of International Women's Day, we honor former Schomburg Center Photographs and Prints Division curator, Dr. Deborah Willis. In this interview, Dr. Willis discusses the BLACK PORTRAITURE[S] III: Reinventions: Strains of Histories and Cultures conference, her photography work, and her pioneering work at The Schomburg Center.

posts.title: Live from the Reading Room: Julian Mayfield to Ruby Dee and Ossie Davis
posts.text: In this letter to friends, Ruby Dee and Ossie Davis, Julian Mayfield discusses his work on a play, world news in Ghana, and a discussion with Malcolm X.

posts.title: Schomburg Research Guide: Katherine Dunham
posts.text: New! This series of Schomburg Center Research Guides will provide you with resources related to various topics and subjects related to the Global Black Experience. This research guide will provide you with an overview of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture’s holdings related to Black dance pioneer, Katherine Dunham.

posts.title: Live from the Reading Room: Nelson Mandela to Niki Iris Xaba
posts.text: Oscar award winning rapper, and actor, Common, recites this heartfelt letter written by Nelson Mandela, to his sister-in-law, Niki Iris Xaba, about family, prison, and his love for then wife, Winnie Mandela.

posts.title: Live from the Reading Room: Langston Hughes to E. Ethelred Brown
posts.text: Robert G. O’Meally, Zora Neale Hurston Professor of English and Comparative Literature and Director of the Center for Jazz Studies at Columbia University recites this letter about faith composed by Harlem Renaissance poet and novelist, Langston Hughes, to Jamaican born Harlem preacher E. Ethelred Brown.

posts.title: Live from the Reading Room: Cheryl Boyce-Taylor to Friends and Poets
posts.text: This episode of 'Live From the Reading Room: Correspondence', recited by Trinidadian costume historian Natalya Mills-Mayrena, features a letter from Trinidadian Poet Cheryl Boyce-Taylor to a group of friends and poets. In the letter, Boyce-Taylor discusses writing, family, and publishing.

posts.title: Live from the Reading Room: Claudia Jones to Eslanda Robeson
posts.text: This podcast episode recited by Carole Boyce Davies features a lively letter between friends and colleagues: Claudia Jones and Eslanda Robeson.

posts.title: Live From the Reading Room: Ada "Bricktop" Smith to Louis "Satchmo" Armstrong
posts.text: Today’s episode features a letter from jazz singer, dancer, and nightclub owner Ada Smith, jazz trumpeter, composer, singer, and "auto-archivist" Louis Armstrong.

posts.title: Live From the Reading Room: Josephine Schuyler to Philippa Schuyler
posts.text: Today’s episode features a letter from journalist and essayist Josephine Schuyler, to her daughter, pianist, composer, journalist, and child prodigy Philippa Duke Schuyler.

posts.title: Live From the Reading Room: Zora Neale Hurston to 'Bill'
posts.text: Today’s episode features a letter from writer, anthropologist, and folklorist, Zora Neale Hurston to her friend, “Bill.”

posts.title: Live From the Reading Room: Claude McKay to Walter White
posts.text: Today’s episode features a letter from Jamaican-American Harlem renaissance era poet and writer Claude McKay to NAACP leader and civil rights activist, Walter White.

posts.title: Live From the Reading Room: Nella Larsen to 'Eddie'
posts.text: Today’s episode features a note from Harlem Renaissance writer Nella Larsen to an unidentified friend—“Eddie”—regarding a social gathering preceding the wedding of Yolande Du Bois and Countee Cullen.

posts.title: Live from the Reading Room: C.L.R. James to Constance Webb
posts.text: Today’s episode features a love letter from Trinidadian social theorist, historian and political activist C.L.R. James (1901-1989) to his wife and confidant the actress, model, writer and activist Constance Webb (1918-2005).

posts.title: Live from the Reading Room: Nathan Woodard to Alice Childress
posts.text: A love letter from musician and composer Nathan Woodard to his wife and creative collaborator Alice Childress.

posts.title: Live from the Reading Room: Aaron Douglas to Alta Sawyer Douglas
posts.text: Today’s episode features a memorable love note from leading Harlem Renaissance painter, illustrator, and graphic artist Aaron Douglas to his wife and life partner Alta Sawyer Douglas, an esteemed educator and Harlemite.

posts.title: Live from the Reading Room: Arturo Schomburg to Langston Hughes
posts.text: Today’s letter features correspondence between Arturo Alfonso Schomburg and Langston Hughes.  In the excerpt below, Schomburg speaks with Hughes regarding acquisitions for The Division of Negro Literature, History and Prints—the forerunner to today’s Schomburg Center.
